nodes.bodyText: Just a general question (will try to review properly shortly):  Should this maybe live in x-pack core since this isn't just a searchable snapshots related piece of functionality and we have plans to use it elsewhere also?

I wanted to keep the scope small here so that we can iterate more quickly on this API. For now, the scope of this is only targeting searchable snapshot investigations. We can at a later stage discuss whether this change is more broadly usable. The main issue with the stats reported here are that they're reset as soon as a repository is updated or a node is restarted, which might make this a confusing API. The core functionality for tracing, that might be useful in the context of Cloud, is in the respective blobstore implementation, and might be exposed differently (e.g. periodic logging)
This fails reproducibly for me with  -Dtests.seed=73DAD8B23C19870D
You probably don't want this filter because it prevents you from seeing the erroneous handlers below in the mapping.

I think we could add a counting http handler that would wrap the handlers (similarly to what ExceptionCatchingHttpHandler does) and that would update counters when receiving an HttpExchange.
I think we're interesting in couting all GETs including the retries?

You could just keep these collectors as fields on S3BlobStore and have getters for them on it?
Then you save adding new fields to the retrying input stream and containers and don't have to create a new instance for every container + get request.
Since it's an inner class, maybe just call it Stats
Can you remove the log message and add them to the assertEquals() methods instead?
I'd move this in a dedicated HttpHandler that would wrap other handlers
Maybe rename this method to merge? (to be consistent with other Stats classes that have similar methods like ForecastStats, SnapshotPolicyStats etc)
Should we catch the repository missing exception here - in case the repository is not yet known by this node - and return empty stats too?
I would like to avoid that as it would then silently provide partial stats
